Evening College tuition hiked
By TOM NATHAN
The Evening College has
announced that commencing
with Summer Session 1973,
tuition will be raised from the
current level of $40 to $45 per
credit.
Roman Verhaalen, dean of the
Evening College, commented,
"When the University made the
decision to raise the tuition for
full time students it was apparent
they would have to raise it in the
Evening College too, but the
amount was undetermined."
The University announced last
October plans to raise the tuition
for full-time undergraduate
students in the Arts and Sciences
division from $2700 to $3000 in
1973-74.
Administrators throughout the
University have been nearly
unanimous in labeling inflation
the chief reason for the increases.
Earlier this year President Muller
acknowledged that costs were
rising by a three per cent
minimum annually.
He stated, "The rising costs of
goods and services, the
imperative to maintain academic
excellence, and the need to
Operate with a balanced budget
compel the University to take
'this step."
The Evening College has
relatively small administrative
and operating costs when
compared to the other divisions
of the University, thus massive
cutbacks were not feasible.
Tuition is the main source of
income for the Evening College
as. outside funding remains
minimal. "Even though there has
been an increase in support for
the Evening College, less than 3%
of the funds needed to support
our program and support services
comes from outside funding

sources," Dean Verhaalen noted.
Despite its comparatively low
overhead, the Evening College
serves nearly one-half the total
Hopkins student population.
Average enrollment during the
Spring and Fall semesters is
approximately 5000 students.
Last year alone, 697 students in
the Evening College received
degrees of some sort.
The tuition increase for the
Evening College is its first since
academic year 1970-71, when the
price was raised from $35 to $40.
The College does not expect to
incur a deficit this year and may
even show a slight surplus
according to Dean Verhaalen. He
predicted, however, that the
Evening College could not hope
to have a balanced budget next
year without the tuition increase.
